articles.title: Gel-coated battery could stop mobile phones catching fire or exploding
articles.description: A cheap and easily manufactured material can act as a thermal conductor at low temperatures and an insulator at high temperatures, which may help prevent dramatic battery fires and explosions
articles.content:
By Matthew Sparkes
Traditional lithium-ion batteries can overheatLithium-ion batteries used in smartphones and other devices are susceptible to catching fire and even exploding if they begin to over… [+477 chars]

articles.title: World's most sensitive dark matter detector tested for the first time
articles.description: A brief test has proven that the new LUX-ZEPLIN dark matter detector is the most sensitive ever. It may be our best bet for finally finding dark matter particles
articles.content:
By Leah Crane
The LUX-ZEPLIN dark matter detector at the Sanford Underground Research Facility in South Dakota is the most sensitive ever

The s… [+2210 chars]

articles.title: Southern fin whales have recovered to large numbers in the Antarctic
articles.description: Aerial surveys have found groups of up to 150 fin whales feeding near Antarctica, a sign that populations have bounced back since since the 1976 ban on hunting these whales
articles.content:
By Jason Arunn Murugesu
A fin whale near Elephant Island, Antarctica
Dan Beecham

articles.title: Meraxes gigas was a huge dinosaur with tiny arms like T. rex
articles.description: A dinosaur discovered in Argentina has been identified as a new species. Meraxes gigas lived 20 million years before T. rex, but had a similarly large body, sharp teeth and proportionately small arms
articles.content:
By Corryn Wetzel
An artist’s illustration of the recently unearthed Meraxes gigas dinosaur
Carlos Papolio
A relatively recently discovered dinosaur species, Meraxes gigas, had a giant body and sma… [+2348 chars]

articles.title: Optimising crop genetics could double global wheat production
articles.description: Optimising the wheat genome could help us double yields of the crop, according to plant scientists – although other researchers say they are being too optimistic

articles.title: Where do the contenders for next UK prime minister stand on science?
articles.description: The race to replace Boris Johnson as UK prime minister has begun, with Suella Braveman and Steve Baker announcing their intention to run. They may be joined by Michael Gove, Rishi Sunak and others, but where do the hopefuls stand on science?
articles.content:

articles.title: Computer component could use as little energy as physically possible
articles.description: Researchers have built a logic gate – a basic computing building block – that uses vibrations for information processing instead of electrons, making it very energy efficient
articles.content:

A mechanical computer component uses membranes thinner than a human hair

articles.title: AI can use your brainwaves to see things that you can't
articles.description: A computer algorithm can use a technique called "ghost imaging" to reconstruct objects from a person's brainwaves that the person themselves can't see

Your brain contains information you can’t access

articles.title: A passing star shifting Neptune’s orbit could wreck the solar system
articles.description: If a star flying past our solar system moved Neptune's orbit by just 0.1 per cent, it could eventually cause the other planets to smash into one another or get thrown out of the solar system entirely
articles.content:
By Leah Crane
If a passing star pushed Neptune a tiny bit further from the sun, it could eventually throw the solar system into chaos
